title: 109_hr2484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Americans in Uniform Act of 2005" and includes a table of contents. The "Americans in Uniform Act of 2005" includes provisions for defense contractors employing reserve component personnel, increasing special pays for reserves, eligibility for burial in Arlington National Cemetery, space-available travel on military aircraft, and a report on employment matters for National Guard and Reserve members. Since September 11, 2001, 424,000 National Guard or Reserve members have been called to active duty, with 357 casualties in the Global War on Terrorism. All 15 Army National Guard brigades have been mobilized in support of operations. Since September 11, 2001, 424,000 National Guard or Reserve members have been called to active duty, with 357 casualties in the Global War on Terrorism. Approximately 34 percent of US troops in Iraq and Kuwait are National Guard or Reserve members, marking the largest mobilization since the Korean War. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF EVALUATION FACTOR FOR DEFENSE CONTRACTORS EMPLOYING OR SUBCONTRACTING WITH MEMBERS OF THE SELECTED RESERVE OF THE RESERVE COMPONENTS OF THE ARMED FORCES. In awarding defense contracts, the Department of Defense must consider whether entities plan to use members of the Selected Reserve for goods and services. Entities must provide documentation of the number of Selected Reserve members they will employ. The Secretary of the military can waive this requirement for national security reasons. The Secretary of the military can waive the requirement for defense contracts involving the Selected Reserve if it is necessary for national security reasons. The Federal Acquisition Regulation will be updated to implement this section. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN VARIOUS SPECIAL PAYS AND ALLOWANCES FOR RESERVE COMPONENT PERSONNEL. Increases in hardship duty pay, reenlistment bonuses, and family separation allowance for reserve component members are proposed. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY OF CERTAIN PERSONS FOR BURIAL IN ARLINGTON NATIONAL CEMETERY. Section 2412 of title 38, United States Code, allows for the burial of certain members or former members of the reserve component of the Armed Forces under 60 years of age in Arlington National Cemetery if they would have been eligible for retired pay under chapter 1223 of title 10. Dependents of those eligible individuals can also be buried in the cemetery. The remains of reserve component members who die in the line of duty can be buried in Arlington National Cemetery, along with their dependents. This includes those on active duty and those on inactive duty training. Arlington National Cemetery allows certain persons to be buried, and the eligibility criteria have been updated. Additionally, certain persons are now eligible for space-available travel on military aircraft. The eligibility criteria for space-available travel on Department of Defense aircraft has been expanded to include reserve retirees under 60 years of age and their spouses who would be eligible for retired pay if not for their age. The eligibility criteria for space-available travel on Department of Defense aircraft has been expanded to include reserve retirees under 60 years of age and their spouses. Space-available travel on Department of Defense aircraft now includes reserve retirees under 60 and their spouses. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within 270 days of this Act on challenges faced by National Guard and Reserve members in employment due to full-time duty. The report will include information on the types and sizes of employers of these members. The report will include details on employers of National Guard and Reserve members, such as the number of employees, self-employment status, nature of business, and reemployment difficulties faced, including those who are disabled or Vietnam Era Veterans.
